channel.title: Comments on: Automatically Version Control Your Jenkins Configuration
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.description: There's no reason it couldn't be run more frequently (for instance, hourly, every 5 minutes, etc), although I agree this solution wouldn't work if you wanted to capture and commit each individual change. I haven't had the need to do that, so i don't know a solution from experience, but the two ways I can think of would be either to see if Jenkins exposes any events when it saves a job configuration or use an external program to monitor for file updates and trigger the commit. Or there is still the option of manually executing the commit. If you find a good solution for this with minimal external management I'd love to hear about it, it would probably be abetter solution that the one I put together here.

item.title: By: chantivlad
item.dc:creator: chantivlad
item.content:encoded:
Hi,

I am interested in such a mechanism, albeit a bit more proactive.
Your solution will work if you change the configuration only once a day.
I would prefer a commit-on-change, like every time the configuration of a job or of jenkins itself is changed, a commit is done.

item.title: By: Graham Smith
item.dc:creator: Graham Smith
item.description: If you add something like "hg add jobs/*/config.xml" to the start of the job, it'll automatically backup any new jobs you create without further intervention.<br /> <br />
